        Consolidated Content:
Roadrunners inhabit the deserts of the southwestern United States, Mexico, and Central America. They live in arid lowland or mountainous shrubland, widely dispersed in dry open country with scattered brush. They are non-migratory, staying in their breeding area year-round. The greater roadrunner is found in the southwestern United States and northern Mexico, including states such as California, Arizona, New Mexico, Texas, Nevada, Utah, Colorado, and Oklahoma. They are opportunistic omnivores, feeding on insects, small reptiles, rodents, small birds, eggs, and fruits and seeds. The roadrunner is one of the few animals that preys upon rattlesnakes and is the only real predator of tarantula hawk wasps.
